title: Heart Attack Emergency Signs
content: A heart attack is a medical emergency. Every minute matters. If you think you or someone else is having a heart attack, call emergency services (112 in Turkey) immediately.
symptoms: Chest pain or discomfort (pressure, squeezing, fullness)
Pain spreading to shoulders, neck, jaw, or arms
what_to_do: Chew an aspirin (300mg) if not allergic
If unconscious and not breathing, begin CPR
do_not: Do not delay calling emergency services
Do not drive yourself to hospital
Do not ignore symptoms hoping they'll pass

title: Stroke Emergency Signs (FAST)
content: Stroke is a medical emergency where blood supply to the brain is interrupted. Use FAST to remember warning signs: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency.
symptoms: Trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance
what_to_do: Keep the person calm and comfortable
Do not give food or water
If unconscious, place in recovery position
fast_test: F - Face: Ask them to smile. Does one side droop?
A - Arms: Ask them to raise both arms. Does one drift down?
S - Speech: Ask them to repeat a simple phrase. Is speech slurred?
T - Time: If any of these signs, call emergency immediately

title: Breathing Difficulty Emergency
content: Severe breathing difficulty is a medical emergency. It can be caused by asthma attacks, allergic reactions, heart problems, or other conditions.
what_to_do: Use EpiPen if allergic reaction and available
Stay calm and reassure the person

title: Severe Bleeding Emergency
content: Severe bleeding can be life-threatening and requires immediate action to stop blood loss while waiting for emergency services.
what_to_do: Apply direct pressure with clean cloth or bandage
Press firmly and do not remove cloth if soaked (add more)
If possible, elevate the injured area above heart
Apply tourniquet only if trained and bleeding is life-threatening

title: Severe Allergic Reaction (Anaphylaxis)
content: Anaphylaxis is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur within minutes of exposure to an allergen. It requires immediate epinephrine and emergency care.
what_to_do: Help person lie down with legs elevated
If breathing difficult, allow to sit up
Second dose of epinephrine after 5-15 min if no improvement

title: Unconscious Person
content: Finding someone unconscious requires quick assessment and action. Check if they're breathing and responsive, and call for emergency help immediately.
what_to_do: Check for danger to yourself and the person
Tap shoulders and shout 'Are you okay?'
Check for breathing (look, listen, feel for 10 seconds)
If breathing: place in recovery position
recovery_position: Place nearest arm at right angle to body
Bring far arm across chest, hold hand against cheek
Pull far knee up, foot flat on ground
Roll person toward you onto their side
Tilt head back to keep airway open
